div1.p: [Carter] describes his first encounter with Finlay and his impressions of Finlay's work.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Juan Guiteras, May 3, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
[unclear]
[unclear]
Washington, D. C.
May 3, 1922.
Dr. Juan Guiteras,
Secretario de Sanidad y Beneficencia,
Habana, Cuba.
Dear Doctor Guiteras:
div1.p:
Thanks for your Martinique article, my Friend. It seems that
we have had the same opinion about la fievre inflammatoire expressed
a little differently. You say “when yellow fever is present it”
(fievre inflammatoire) “is yellow fever and when there was no yellow
fever, it was something else.” I said “in this disease were included
cases of yellow fever not recognized as such: dengue and its congeners
and other diseases dhowing approximately the same initial symptoms.”

It is worth noting, however, that in the very complete account
of disease in the French Antilles, up to and including Cornilliac any-
way, neither dengue nor six day fever figured; as the epidemic of 1860,
described as F. I. by Ballot, was clearly either of these two--the
latter probably the same that we had in Porto Rico.

What I meant about Finlay was this: All that I had ever seen
of his work, until you sent me his book, was (1) a brief review, in the
American Journal of Medical Sciences in the spring of 1882 just be-
fore I went to California, of one of his papers--the original one, I
think: (2) wheat was given in Sternberg's Report on his tetrad coccus,
published by the M. H. H.

I met him on the street cars, going out to the Vedado, Jan. 1899,
and, finding that I did not know my way, he introduced himself and I
,
I,
2.
recalling the paper I first referred to, asked if he was the author of
it. Thus began our friendship, for it was this, not a mere acquain-
tance. He naturally talked about his views, but while as a writer he
was clear and logical to a degree, in conversation he was, to me, not
convincing. He would usually take as a basis of argument data which I
did not consider established: For instance, I was giving him what I
considered sufficient reasons--the same that I gave Reed in 1900--for
the innocuousness of fabrics as vectors of yellow fever (giving him sta-
tistics of the enormous number of trunks and boxes that had gone into
New York during the summer time from Habana and Vera Cruz without giving
rise to the disease) and he answered calmly that fabrics could not pos-
sibly carry yellow fever unless a mosquito was in the box with them.
This he stated doubtless occurred and explained the cases reported.

I was, as you know, essentially a field officer--naturally a student,
but from force of circumstances able to be so only incidentally. I was
interested in yellow fever only from the time I went to Ship Island in
1888, where I had only such books as I could afford to buy myself. Finlay
never offered to show me any of his reprints on this subject, and I did
not have any knowledge of it save from the sources I have named, nor
had I heard of Ross' work until I left Cuba in the fall of 1900. Yet
I never considered his claim as “unreasonable” as Sternberg character-
izes it, only as having no sufficient reason shown therefor. I am very
sure that if I had read his various publications on this subject, I
would have held his views as at least extremely probable and would have
plead for an experimental test. With my knowledge of the interval of
time between the date an environment receives infection and the date at
which it becomes infective (the “extrinsic incubation of yellow fever”)--
in which, by the way, he never seemed at all interested--he would have
kept his mosquitoes about 15 days after the contaminative feeding before
before 3.
applying them to the man he would infect. It was from not doing this
that his experiments failed. They did fail, and yet I cannot explain
even now the apparent immunity of the clerics, whom he had subjected to
mosquito inoculation.

In 1899 Las Animas was reported as non-infectable and we, at my
instance, put out a number of quinine bottles half filled with water to
determine the species of mosquitoes that were breeding there, arguing
that if there were no Culex icteroides--as we called it then--it would
be a strong point in favor of it being the vector, and also I agreed to
have this same insect sought for in the different infectable and non-in-
fectable places of the South as soon as I got back to the U. S. We
had no Stegomyiae from our bottles up to the time I left, but, naturally,
before the next summer, Reed's experiments had been done.

Laura joins me in love to yourself and in very best remembrances
to Mrs. Guiteras.
